name: Qatar
takeaway: In the Academia Domain, not much data was observed other than a Mandarin language curriculum has been included in several universities in Qatar.
In the Domestic Politics Domain, there have been several visits by Qatari politicians and government officials to China, though data in this Domain is in general hard to come by.

Technology has also become an interesting and more important sector in bilateral relations between Qatar and the PRC. Technological cooperation with China was well established long pior to the 2022 FIFA World Cup. Qatar and China are encouraging strategic cooperation to optimize the use of 5G networks, big data, cloud computing, and remote medical care. Besides, the Digital Silk Road is implemented through cooperation on the development of Smart Cities in several cities in Qatar.

TikTok is the Chinese application most used by Qatari people. Qatari people have positive views of China and there are Lunar New Year events that have been organized by the Chinese embassy or Qatari businesses.

Qatar has good relations with China in the Military Domain. Both countries established various collaborations, one of which is military exchanges. Qatar has also purchased many weapons from China since 2014.
In the Law Enforcement Domain, Qatar and China agreed to cooperate in anti-terrorism campaigns.
description-1: In 2023, Qatar had a GDP per capita of US$87,480 and a total population of 2.95 million people.
description-2: Qatar established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1988. Qatar was ranked 84th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Not Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 25/100.

Media.evidence: None of the sources mention any connection to the World Chinese Media (世界华文媒体) network in Qatar.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There is no specific mention of Qatari journalists or media organizations being members of the aforementioned networks.

Media.evidence: There is no direct evidence of Qatari journalists participating in PRC-organized international travel programs. Without specific information confirming the involvement of Qatari journalists or influencers in such programs, this aspect of the question cannot be definitively confirmed.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Chinese media outlets plan to open offices at Qatar Media City, with increased media cooperation and the establishment of a Chinese cultural center and Confucius Academy. However, there is no evidence indicating that Qatari journalists, media organizations, or influencers receive training from PRC entities.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Chinese state media CGTN and CCTV which have special Arabic language channels in Qatar,
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Most media outlets in Qatar are owned by the state, royal family members, or their affiliates. Major Qatari media entities include Qatar Media Corporation (state-owned), Al Jazeera (government-funded), and various pro-government newspapers and radio stations. No evidence indicates PRC ownership or control of Qatari media outlets.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence:
Qatar News Agency (QNA) Director-General Ahmed bin Saeed Al Rumaihi met with a delegation from China's Xinhua News Agency in Doha. The meeting aimed to strengthen media cooperation, focusing on exchanging expertise, developing news services, and enhancing collaboration between the two agencies.

Al Jazeera Media Network has a formal partnership with China Intercontinental Communication Center (CICC) involving media exchange agreements, co-production of content, and broadcasting Chinese documentaries on the Al Jazeera documentary channel. The partnership also includes a weekly program called "USilk" (52 episodes) that showcases Chinese society and culture, as well as the distribution and marketing of jointly produced media content.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There is no evidence indicating that Qatari local newspapers, online news websites, content farms, or social media platforms receive regular advertising support from PRC-connected entities. The available evidence only shows World Cup-specific advertising and sponsorship rather than ongoing advertising relationships with Qatari media outlets.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: There is no specific evidence indicating direct PRC pressure on journalists in Qatar.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Recent coverage of Qatar-China relations frequently employs emotive language to highlight the closeness of their partnership. Descriptions emphasize the strengthening of ties, stating that "the friendship between China and Qatar has become closer and closer over time." The pandas sent to Qatar are portrayed as "envoys of friendship between the Chinese and Qatari people," symbolizing the bond between the nations. The relationship is further characterized by "mutual trust" that has "continued to deepen," and the past decade is referred to as a "golden decade" of development, underscoring the positive and prosperous nature of their cooperation.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Qatar is one of the countries that rejected the proposal to discuss the Uigur Muslim issue at the UN.
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence:
Qatar has indeed taken significant steps to attract foreign investments with the establishment of the Qatar Free Zones Authority (QFZA) in 2018. While the specific targeting of Chinese investments is not explicitly mentioned, the investment-friendly climate and incentives provided in these free zones are likely to be attractive to investors from various countries, including China.

Also, If the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), of which Qatar is a member, decides to relax regulations or establish agreements to facilitate investment and trade with China, Qatar, as part of the GCC, would be involved and impacted by these decisions. Agreements or policy changes made at the GCC level typically apply to all member states, which include Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: The Qatari government has not specifically set a policy to relax special economic zones in an effort to attract investment from China, but more broadly the GCC has done this to partner with China.
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Economy.evidence: We are unable to find any source which indicates it
Economy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: The main telecom providers in Qatar are Ooredoo Group, Vodafone Group, Etisalat, and Starlink for satellite services. Huawei, a Chinese company, operates as a technology and equipment provider but not as a telecom service provider in Qatar. The market is primarily dominated by Ooredoo (Qatar-based) and Vodafone (UK-based), with the recent addition of Starlink. There is no indication that China Mobile, China Unicom, China Telecom, or their subsidiaries operate as telecom providers in Qatar.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Qatar-based Ooredoo Group announced on Saturday (7 March 2020) its selection of China’s Huawei Technologies as its strategic partner to fully enable 5G networks and services across five countries
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: In 2022, the global spotlight will shift to Qatar, host of the FIFA World Cup, which represents a significant milestone as the first time the event has been held in the Middle East. The 2022 World Cup will bring around 1.7 million visitors to Qatar, which is itself a small nation of 2.7 million people. To make it the first 5G World Cup with services such as 8K live broadcasts and augmented and virtual reality, Qatar’s Vodafone partnered with Huawei, while the country’s other carrier, Ooredoo, partnered with Ericsson and Nokia.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Qatar Ministry offers market for CCTV surveillance to China. The Qatari government has subscribed to Dahua and Hikvision companies, which are CCTV companies from China, since 2016. Apart from that, China also supplies video surveillance equipment for civil and military purposes in Qatar.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Technology.evidence: Qatar is collaborating to procure facial recognition technology with Russia, but in 2023 there is information that the Qatari government plans to explore facial recognition collaboration with China.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: During the Qatar World Cup, a young prince named Abdulrahman Fahad al-Thani went viral among Chinese people via TikTok, because of his popularity he opened an official account on Douyin, the Chinese version of TikTok and has millions of followers. Apart from that, he also opened a Weibo account with hundreds of thousands of followers. Apart from that, there are also many content creators from Qatar who are popular on TikTok with millions of followers. TikTok is the Chinese application most used by Qatari people.
Society.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Society.evidence: At the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, China's presence is very prominent. This can be seen from the total amount of sponsorship from Chinese companies which reached $1.4 billion. Chinese companies that are official sponsors of the 2022 World Cup include Wanda Group, Hisense Group, Vivo and dairy company Mengniu.
